title: What are some of the best, most surprising, covers of original songs made famous by other musicians? - Quora

response.answer_text: Okay, I'll take a swing at this ... tho my answer is much too obvious … In 1967, a band you may-or-may-not have ever heard of released an album ... and the second track was a little silly-song, set in a ‘make-believe live setting', the singer was given a make-believe name ... he was singing about his band-mates, a make-believe band. He was in a band that wasn't performing or anything, just a studio bunch. It was a pleasant song, very pleasant actually ... a happy, whimsical-type song about friendship ... and we (of the era) used to use a line from it as a 'common tag-line' at the time. Then, two years later in 1969, a completely unknown guy recorded the song and released it as a single, and as the title track to an album of the same name. Both the original singer and the cover-guy were from the north of England, from industrial cities about 100 miles apart ... both very likable guys, with similar strong 'accents' from the area. The '69 cover-album only charted around #30(ish) in both the US and in the UK ... the single didn't reach the Top 50 in the US, but it shot to #1 in the UK. I saw the cover-performer on stage twice, at the Eastowne Theater in Detroit right around that time, circa 1970. He was well-known for this song at the time ... he sang a very emotional version of it, with a great organ and lead guitar intro ... and since he gave the appearance of possibly being slightly physically handicapped or impaired, his performance -- standing up while seemingly having a slight issue with keeping his balance and all -- drew heartfelt emotion from everyone in the audience ... we loved it. Turns out, however, that ‘thing he was doing with his body’ while singing was not due to any disability or ailment whatsoever. He was fine. And he said many times, in explanation, that he’d just ‘go into a zone’ during a song, and that that’s what would happen … he was playing ‘air-guitar,’ and ‘air-organ’ and ‘directing the band’ …he was just being in the moment. Here he is, performing the song ... at a little venue called Woodstock I believe (in upstate New York I guess, I've vaguely heard of it) ... 1969.   BTW, DID YOU KNOW: for the recording of this Joe Cocker (RIP, 2014 .. see: Thomas J. Beaver's answer to What health problems did Joe Cocker suffer from?) version of the song, it was Jimmy Page playing the opening riff (that sneaky guy pops up everywhere!), and Page’s friend Procol Harum drummer B.J. Wilson (RIP) was on the drums ... plus esteemed sessions keyboardist Tommy Eyre (RIP, who recorded with BB King, John Mayall, and on Gerry Rafferty's great recordings of "Baker Street" and "Right Down The Line") created the opening organ riff. On the road, the guitarist was Henry McCullough (RIP, from Spooky Tooth and later Paul McCartney's Wings), and then on the 1970 Mad Dogs and Englishman tour which I saw, on lead guitar was Leon Russell … and on keyboards the great Chris Stainton … RIta Cooledge was up there as well, as a backup singer, and her boyfriend Jim Gordon (who later stole“Layla” from RIta) and Jim Keltner on drums … Chris Radle (RIP) on bass … the brilliant producer Denny Cordell was having fun as a backup singer as well. Paul McCartney, a rather obscure British recording artist (you may-or-may-not have heard of him …decent musician and all) who wrote the song, said about Cocker's version: "He was a lovely northern lad who I loved a lot and, like many people, I loved his singing. I was especially pleased when he decided to cover "With a Little Help from My Friends" and I remember him and Denny Cordell (Procol Harum's producer, as well as Cocker’s) coming round to the studio in Saville Row (central London) and playing me what they'd recorded — and it was just mind-blowing, totally turned the song into a soul anthem, and I was forever grateful to him for doing that." And here's the original singer, some guy name-a Ringo ... along with that writer of the tune (still good-looking in 2009) ... maybe meeting for the first time ever right here onstage(???), and playing it together!

I scrolled through all 94 answers, and there isn't but maybe a handful of original answers here. You have too many of the exact same answers, not to mention the reccuring covers being named that are in no way responsible for making the songs famous. I prefer not to add famous covers to my answer that have been named fifty times already in different answers. I also vow not to add any cover of a famous song just because I like somebody's newer version, since your question wasn't asking for covers of already made famous songs. So, what are some of the best covered songs that have been made famous by other musicians? Well… In 1986, the vocal powerhouse Tina Turner released a single which featured an original song written just for her titled “Don't Turn Around”. Surprisingly, the song still wasn't made famous even after Neil Diamond covered it in 1992. The band that made it famous was Ace of Base after they recorded it in 1994. This is the famous version by Ace of Base…   Moon Martin sang “Bad Case of Loving You (Doctor, Doctor)” in 1978, but Robert Palmer made it very famous in 1979. Here is Robert Palmer making it famous…   Jimmie Driftwood wrote and recorded “The Battle Of New Orleans” in 1958, but Johnny Horton made it famous in 1959. This is the famous Johnny Horton version…   Lou Johnson came out with “Always Something There to Remind Me” in 1964, but it wasn't made famous until a band named Naked Eyes recorded it in 1983. This is that version that made it famous…   Percy Sledge recorded “When a Man Loves a Woman” in 1967, but it was made famous by Michael Bolton in 1991…   “Magic Bus” was recorded by Pudding in 1967, but it was The Who that made it famous in 1968…   In 1966, Art Reynolds Singers recorded “Jesus Is Just Alright”, but it was the Doobie Brothers that made it famous in 1972…   In 1968, Jerry Jeff Walker recorded “Mr. Bojangles”, but the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band made it famous in 1970. Here is the version of “Mr. Bojangles” that we all know and love…   In 1957, Dale Hawkins recorded “Susie Q”, but Creedence Clearwater Revival made it famous in 1968 with this sound…   "Angel of the Morning" was written in the 60s originally for Connie Francis. After she turned it down, two singers by the names of Billie Davis and Danny Michaels ended up recording it in '67. Merilee Rush had some success covering it the following year, but the cover that really made the song famous was Juice Newton's version, which came out in 1981…   When I was a kid, one of my most favorite and beloved songs of the 80’s was actually a cover. A famous cover at that. “I Think We're Alone Now" might have been originally written just for Tommy James and the Shondells, and even though it became a hit reaching to #4 on the Billboard Hot 100, it was made most famous by Tiffany when she recorded it in 1987, and I played it over and over and over and over again in my Walkman…

The best example, for me, of a cover song that surpasses the original is Bob Dylan’s All Along the Watchtower as performed by Jimi Hendrix. Jimi transformed a tight little folk song into an apocalyptic rocker while still paying attention to the words. Dylan’s version of the song appeared on the acoustic album “John Wesley Harding,” Dylan’s first album after his motorcycle accident up in Woodstock, New York. The production on the album was spare, almost severe. It featured Bob’s guitar strumming, Charlie McCoy’s acoustic bass and Kenneth Buttrey’s drums. These are Nashville session musicians, so they know how to keep it tight. The last two songs on the album featured Pete Drake’s pedal steel guitar. So , the song has an insistent beat, a simple chord progression and mysterious lyrics that seem meaningful. Bob sings the song urgently. In three perfectly constructed verses and one Bob Dylan harmonica solo the song is over. The song spoke to Jimi Hendrix when he heard it, clearly. He recorded it for his album Electric Ladyland. He kept adding and deleting parts for nearly three months. The final recording of the song is a triumph of mixing as different parts of what he recorded are brought into focus throughout the song. Jimi sings with energy and it sounds like he means it. Jimi gets the song and turns it into a hit rock single that is still played today. The full power of the song is still intact and able to move the listener even now, after all these years. In the booklet that came with the Biograph set, Bob Dylan wrote, "I liked Jimi Hendrix's record of this (All Along the Watchtower) and ever since he died I've been doing it that way... Strange how when I sing it, I always feel it's a tribute to him in some kind of way."

There are a lot of great answers to this question. Until The Beatles came along, most pop stars (including Elvis) did not write their own material, opting for professional songwriters. Even The Beatles themselves did a lot of covers, especially in their early days. Speaking of The Beatles, how’s this for some trivia? Who is the only other band besides them to be involved in four of the top five billboard songs at one time? If you said The Bee Gees in 1977, you’re right. I bring this up because in 1978, Bee Gees producer had a seemingly great idea: Why not make a movie of the Bee Gees (along with Peter Frampton) singing Beatles songs? What could go wrong? Not to be too snarky, but plenty. I’ve seen the movie once and that was enough for me. Besides the almost Fab Four from above, an eclectic group of rock stars and celebrities were brought in to sing songs. George Burns sang “Fixing a Hole” and Steve Martin sang “Maxwell’s Silver Hammer.” Rotten Tomatoes gave it a 12% rating. There were two lone bright spots: Aerosmith and Earth, Wind, and Fire performed two amazing covers.   The movie didn’t do much for the careers of the Bee Gees, Peter Frampton, and most of the other guest artists. But these two covers are as good as any Beatles covers I’ve ever heard. How the 'Sgt. Pepper's' Movie Derailed Two Careers

I see a lot of long-haired hippy rock down below. Let me represent Traditional Country Music. OK, let’s begin with a recent hit for Chris Stapleton. Many people already realize “Tennessee Whiskey” is a cover of George Jones.  What many don’t realize is George Jones actually covered this song. It was written and originally recorded by David Allan Coe.  Digging back a bit further, Gene Watson is well known for “Farewell Party.” You might say it is his most famous song and it’s considered a franchise song as he does it at every concert. What many don’t know (including me before the magic of the interwebs) is that it’s actually a cover of Waylon Jennings from 10 years earlier.  The next one may be considered a Country Standard since so many big names have covered it. I was playing an open mic one night and we started discussing this song. Some in the loose band thought it was Keith Whitley original. Others said it was Merle Haggard. It’s also been covered by Sturgill Simpson, Gene Watson, Kenny Chestnut, Daryle Singletary and many others. The other players didn’t believe me when I said it was originally Lefty Frizzel that recorded “I Never Go Around Mirrors.”  Finally, Hank Williams was known as “The Lovesick Blues Boy” because he received so many encores when he performed this song on The Grand Ol’ Opry. (or was it the Louisiana Hayride?) (or both?)  But, this was a cover. Yep, Lovesick Blues was written before Hank was even born and originally recorded in 1925. My apologies….. It’s the only video I could find.  EDIT: While researching a comment below, I realized that one of my favorite Red Dirt songs is actually a cover. Emily Herring had a hit on the Red Dirt/Outlaw scene with “Midnight.”  Well, wouldn’t you know it. It’s a cover.

“All Along the Watchtower” was written by Bob Dylan. Jimi Hendrix and the Experience covered and scored ol’ Jimi’s only top forty hit. It’s said that Dylan feels this is the best cover version of one of his songs ever recorded.  “I Heard It Through the Grapevine” written by Marvin Gaye was covered with success by Creedence Clearwater Revival. In a somewhat counterintuitive move John Fogerty and the boys turned it into a barroom boogie jam-slam. Here’s the single version-  On the Cosmos Factory album the song is extended with a blistering jam. “Without You” is a Badfinger song. Their version is okay, but Harry Nilsson took it and made it a hit with what many consider one of the best vocal performances ever recorded.  “Ain’t Too Proud to Beg” was a hit for The Temptations and The Rolling Stones cover broke the top twenty as well. Mick & Co showed you could rock-up a pop/soul tune and make it work.  “Tainted Love” was a big hit for Soft Cell. Thought it was their song did ya? Nope. It was originally recoded by Gloria Jones for Motown in 1964.

I think I’ve answered a couple of questions that are very close to this one (Ben Waggoner's answer to Peter Gabriel’s cover of the ‘Boy in the Bubble’ song changed the tempo and mood of the original song. What other cover songs totally transformed a song? and Ben Waggoner's answer to What is your favorite cover song? , but what the heck, I ain’t done. . . This is “just” a high school ensemble—Poteet High School, in Mesquite, Texas, had a percussion ensemble that just hit Emerson, Lake, and Palmer’s “Karn Evil 9, 1st Impression, Part 2” out of the goddamn ballpark. They did add a guitarist, a synth player, and a damn good vocalist, but an awful lot of what you’re hearing is a bunch of xylophones and vibes. This has long been a favorite of mine.   The Swingle Singers are famous for their renditions of Bach. . .   New Orleans jazz-funk-rock masters Johnny Sketch and the Dirty Notes give the treatment to Rush’s “Red Lenses”. . .   Tori Amos covered Nirvana’s “Smells Like Teen Spirit” as only she could do it. . .  In fact, Tori Amos did a lot of covers—including a whole album of them, Strange Little Girls. This included one that completely deconstructs the original, while at the same time staying dead on point: her version of Slayer’s “Raining Blood”. . . .   I’m not quite sure how I feel about Rob Zombie’s cover of the Ramones’ “Blitzkrieg Bop”. . . it’s different, anyway. . .   Beth Patterson did an Indian-inflected cover of Black Sabbath’s “Air Dance” that I really like. . . .   I think I already posted one Apocalyptica cover, but what the heck, here’s Metallica’s “Fade to Black.” Face it: the cello is freakin’ metal—and achingly beautiful. . . .   And because some of these covers are kind of sad and creepy and depressing, I’ll leave you with “Weird Al” Yankovic. Every one of his albums includes a medley of pop tunes of the day played in polka style. . . except for one: Alapalooza featured “Bohemian Polka,” a complete cover of Queen’s “Bohemian Rhapsody,” not a parody with rewritten lyrics, but given the Weird Al treatment from beginning to end:

You’ve heard of Harry Nilsson. You’ve heard of Mariah Carey. And many others (180 of them) who recorded a song described by Paul McCartney as “the killer song of all time”. But have you heard of Pete Ham and Tom Evans who wrote “Without You” as a modest album track for their band, Badfinger? It appeared on their 1970 album “No Dice” and was never considered worth releasing as a single. Rolling Stone magazine welcome Badfinger’s debut album as "It's as if John, Paul, George, and Ringo had been reincarnated”. Both McCartney and Harrison, separately, produced some of their songs. Personally, I think this song is probably cursed. Badfinger fell in with one of the few people in the world I would describe as truly evil, US “businessman” (possibly mafioso) Stan Polley. A financial statement prepared by Polley's accountants, Sigmund Balaban & Co., for the period from 8 December 1970 to 31 October 1971, showed Polley's income from the band: "Salaries and advances to client, $8,339 (Joey Molland), $6,861 (Mike Gibbins), $6,211 (Tom Evans), $5,959 (Pete Ham). Net corporation profit, $24,569. Management commission, $75,744 (Stan Polley)". That was a lot of money in 1971 (equivalent to around $500,000 today). Badfinger - Wikipedia His, well, blatant thefts eventually led to the collapse of the band, and one of those great “what might have been” musical questions. Polley was convicted for fraud, unrelated to Badfinger, and was named in Senate hearings as the conduit between (unnamed) organised crime figures and a New York judge. He died in 2009. Stan Polley - Wikipedia Arguments about royalties for the song carried on forever. In 1975 Pete Ham committed suicide. In 1983, Tom Evans committed suicide. Both died poor. "The music business is a cruel and shallow money trench, a long plastic hallway where thieves and pimps run free, and good men die like dogs. There's also a negative side." -- Hunter S. Thompson.

I’m going to go really out there with these but I really like these 10: -Running Up That Hill by Placebo - they preserved the intensity of Kate Bush’s original -Use Me by Isaac Hayes - takes the Bill Withers original and turns it into a long funky groove. Sit back and enjoy. -Ride Like the Wind and Court of the Crimson King by Saxon - they make the Christopher Cross original heavier and Crimson King has metal majesty. They preserve the dynamics of the original -Folsom Prison Blues by Everlast - very faithful yet hip hop style cover of the Johnny Cash song -Alone Again Or - originally by Love, covered well by the Damned and UFO. You can tell that these bands loved this beautiful song. -Beechwood Park - original by The Zombies, covered by Beck. Beautiful. -Border Song by Aretha Franklin, originally by Elton John - she delivers a great cover. So much power! -Triad by David Crosby - originally by Jefferson Airplane. Subject matter’s a bit dicey but the recorded version is Crosby in fine sweet voice and harmony. -Baby Come Back - original by Desmond Dekker, cover by Eddy Grant - strong vocals and rockin arrangement make this a great cover

I was surprised that Sinéad O’Connor’s ‘Nothing Compares 2 U’ was penned by Prince and recorded this song in 1984, but didn't release it.  When Sinéad cried in the video, it was a real tear. You could feel it, it was touching. "All Along the Watchtower" by Jimi Hendrix (originally by Bob Dylan) - was like the song of the decade for me; Hendrix was electrifying, vocal and guitar. I only realized it was Dylan’s composition when I read the fine print. Surprise, surprise.  Ok I know this is The Beatles, but when Joe Cocker came out with it, I was stunned - it was recorded in 3/4 time - a waltz; The Beatles original version was in traditional 4/4 time.  Jimmy Page played guitar, BJ Wilson from Procol Harum played drums, and a gospel choir sang background on this track - the icing on the cake that made the song legendary. When reggae group UB40 recorded and released "Red Red Wine," even they didn't know who the original artist was. (err… me too). The song was written and recorded in the late 1960s by Neil Diamond (one of my favourite singers).  Lead singer Ali Campbell recalls in the book 1000 UK #1 Hits: "The funny thing about the song is we only knew it as a reggae song. We had no idea that Neil Diamond wrote it." Red Red Wine by UB40 - Songfacts

Sloop John B by The Beach Boys (Kingston Trio cover) Twist and Shout by The Beatles (Isley Brothers cover) Hard to Handle by Black Crowes (Otis Redding cover) All the Way by Bob Dylan (Frank Sinatra cover) I Feel For You by Chaka Khan (Prince cover) All Along the Watchtower by Jimi Hendrix (Bob Dylan cover) Hound Dog by Elvis Presley (Sister Rosetta Thorpe cover) Knockin On Heaven’s Door by Guns n Roses (Bob Dylan cover) That’s Life by Frank Sinatra (OC Smith covet) Shameless by Garth Brooks (Billy Joel cover) Got My Mind Set on You by George Harrison (James Ray cover) Love is Blindness by Jack White (U2 cover) Somewhere Over the Rainbow/What a Wonderful World by Israel Kamakawiwoʻole (Judy Garland / Louis Armstrong cover medley) Hallelujah by Jeff Buckley (Leonard Cohen cover) Can’t Take My Eyes Off of You by Lauryn Hill (Frank Valli cover) You Shook Me by Led Zeppelin (Muddy Waters cover) I’m a Believer by the Monkees (Neil Diamond cover) Physical (You’re so) by Nine Inch Nails (Adam and the Ants cover) The Man Who Sold the World by Nirvana (David Bowie cover) Last Kiss by Pearl Jam (Wayne Cochran cover) Femme Fatale by REM (Velvet Underground cover) Have I Told You Lately by Rod Stewart (Van Morrison cover) Time is in My Side by Rolling Stones (Kai Winding and His Orchestra cover) Style by Ryan Adams (Taylor Swift cover) Nothing Compares 2 U by Sinead O’Connor (Prince cover) Landslide by Smashing Pumpkins (Fleetwood MAC cover) For Once in My Life by Stevie Wonder (Jean DuShon cover) Take Me to the River by Talking Heads (Al Green cover) Dead Flowers by Townes Van Zandt (Rolling Stones cover) Blinded By the Light by Mannfred Mann (Bruce Springsteen cover) I Say a Little Prayer by Aretha Franklin (Dionne Warwick cover) Respect by Aretha Franklin (Otis Redding cover) Someday We’ll Be Together by Supremes (Johnny and Jackey cover)
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Barbara Young Capalbo

response.answer_text: Well there are really an awful lot of them and then if you add the songs that were written by other people for the band or artist the list just grows to beyond control…. But I'll throw my hat in with my list of good to great covers…… "Hound Dog" - Elvis Presley "A Taste of Honey" - Herb Alpert & the Tijuana Brass "A Taste of Honey"- the Beatles "Black Magic Woman"... and...."She's Not There" - Santana's "With a Little Help from My Friends"- Joe Cocker “I Heard It Through the Grapevine”- Creedence Clearwater Revival “All Along the Watchtower” - Jimi Hendrix “Without You” - Harry Nilsson "Where Have All the Flowers Gone"- Peter, Paul & Mary Mighty Quinn (Quinn the Eskimo)" - Manfred Mann "Hallelujah" - Jeff Buckley "Mr. Tamborine Man" - The Byrds "Hurt"- Johnny Cash "Get Ready"- Rare Earth "Blinded By The Light" - Manfred Mann "The Sound of Silence"- Disturbed "Me & Bobby McGee"- Janis Joplin "Knockin On Heavens Door"- Guns n’ Roses "Red Red Wine" - UB40 "Blue Bayou" - Linda Ronstadt "Time After Time"- Cyndi Lauper "Hazy Shade of Winter"- the Bangles "Past the Point of Rescue" - Hal Ketchum

I’ll preface this with the caveat that I’m a bit of an old goth. But some old goth bands have some magnificent cover versions… Jolene, Sisters of Mercy. She better keep off of his man:  Emma, Sisters of Mercy. Hot Chocolate’s best song. Brown’s scream at the end of the original is chilling. The cover is epic:  In Every Dream home a Heartache, Fields of the Nephilim. Slow burn on this, but explodes at the end. The most emotion anyone has ever had about a rubber doll.  Tomorrow Never Knows, The Mission. Sorry John, not enough chords lets add some…  Dream on, The Mission. Anthemic you say Mr Tyler? Let's add some bombast. (OK probably the most straight cover on here but still. It’s awesome live)  In The Year 2525 Fields of the Nephilim, I love the original but this is extraordinary, you can feel the darkness of Cthulhu, the dread of a cold universe that cares not for your feeble life.  Like a Hurricane, The Mission. OK, let’s just say the original has the two best guitar breaks in the history of all music. No one in the Mission can ever dream of bettering that, but they have turned a brittle precious jewel into a stomper of a sing-a-long.  There are many more great goth covers. Let me know if you need more…

Here is an interesting Rolling Stones anecdote. Believe it or not, the Rolling Stones’ debut album was all cover songs, mostly Mississippi blues and early R&R related songs done in their own style.  It was a successful debut. The Stones’ manager at the time was Andrew Loog Oldham. He knew the boys needed original tunes if they wanted to enjoy serious commercial success, so he sat Mick and Keith down at the kitchen table in the house they were renting at the time and instructed them to brainstorm an original song and not to get out of that kitchen until they had finished their collaboration. They did write a deep melodramatic love song, but on review, thought the song a little too, too, how would you say it, delicate - no, uh, sappy? But, they all three recognized it as a potentially great piece of work so they decided to let an up and coming R&R diva have a go at recording it. It was given to Mary Ann Faithful. She made it into a success. The song? “As Tears Go By”. The Rolling Stones recorded a cover of their own song, after the Mary Ann Faithful cover had made it a hit. How's that for Rock & Roll history?

Tears for Fears had a great song., “Mad World”, in 1982:  And I wasn’t even aware of the cover made of it by Gary Jules and Michael Andrews for Donnie Darko:  until I started to write this answer and found that my favorite version of the song was a cover of their cover, by Adam Lambert in 2009 for “final 8” night of American Idol, which I think is just flat out masterful:  Also, Disturbed’s cover (2015) of Simon and Garfunkel’s The Sound of Silence I found to be beyond the original - I literally stopped everything when I stumbled upon this in my music streaming service:  and - to be fair - I REALLY liked the original from 1966:  And the third that sprang immediately to mind when I saw this question: another Tears for Fears track, “Shout”, from 1984  I find I prefer Disturbed’s 2000 cover of this, which feels more raw to me:

My vote would go to….Tori Amos, who is a great songwriter in her own right. She actually released an album of cover versions. But in live concerts she used to cover songs you wouldn't think a sort of Kate Bush sounding woman would try. At number 2 I would vote her sweet slow rendition of Whole Lotta Love originally (sort of) by Led Zeppelin. Using piano instead of guitar and still having an orgasm. But at number 1 is Smells like teen spirit by Nirvana ( 90s band not the 60s one) Nirvana actually used this song over the PA at the start of their concerts. I was never sure if that was the bands pi..take or if they really liked the Tori version. Her version makes the song even sadder and you don't even realise the guitar riff is missing. Others would include Twist and Shout covered by the Beatles changing the song from singing about a dance to singing about sex and James Taylor taking the lead vocal ( instead of Backing) on Carol Kings , You've got a friend .
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Barbara Young Capalbo

response.answer_text: People have already listed many excellent covers, but I have to point out this one: Love’s cover of the Bacharach/David song “My Little Red Book”. (I hasten to add that it has nothing to do with Chairman Mao; I don’t know why it’s not “little black book”, which is the term I’d always heard used for a small address/phone book of potential, um, partners.) Anyway… during this era Bacharach was doing stuff with groups like Manfred Mann, who performed this song for What’s New Pussycat? (which I suspect people remember more for Tom Jones’s performance of the title song). The lyrics are from the POV of someone who has lost his love and, no matter how many women from his little red book he goes out with, can’t get over her. The Manfred Mann version is full of jazzy chords that give the lie to the lyrics, especially at the end of the chorus, with a dazzling alternating EM7 and CM7 that suggest that the guy’s private jet has just climbed out of the clouds heading west towards the sunset and to his place in Hawai`i—he’s already forgotten whoever the $EXPLETIVE he was singing about. The Love version, though, is minimalist and raw—kind of proto-punk. They simplified the chord progression and stripped the instrumentation down to the bare minimum. Bacharach did not appreciate the changed progressions, and probably didn’t like the discordances they added, but they fit the lyrics. This guy is really suffering. Compare Manfred Mann’s delivery with Arthur Lee’s. Mann croons “There is just no getting over you”, the melodic line ending with a B smoothly fitting the EM7 and CM7. How different Lee and Love! Lee belts “THERE’S JUST NO GETTING OVER YOU, O-OH NO-O-O-O….” with “you” and “no” intentionally grating against the chords they’re sung over. Bacharach did many great sad songs, most notably IMHO “Trains and Boats and Planes”, showing you can be sophisticated and hurting…. but the original form of “My Little Red Book” just doesn’t cut it. Arthur Lee and Love made it work and made it great.

Many instrumental hits of the early sixties were ‘suped-up’ versions of the classics, such as: The William Tell Overture both as ‘Piltdown Rides Again’ (The Piltdown Men) and ‘Apple Knocker’ (B.Bumble & The Stingers); Swan Lake as ‘Saturday Nite at the Duckpond’ (The Cougars); The Nutcracker Suite as ‘Nut Rocker’ (B.Bumble & The Stingers); ‘Morning’ from Grieg’s Pier Gynt suite as ‘Dawn Cracker’ (B.Bumble & The Stingers); Czardas by Monti as ‘Czardas’ (Nero and The Gladiators); In the Hall of the Mountain King by Grieg as: ‘In the Hall of the Mountain King’ (Nero & The Gladiators); Tchaikovsky’s Piano Concerto as ‘Red Square’ (The Cougars); Russian song Polyuschka-Polye both as ‘Samovar’ (Krew Kats) and ‘Rocket Man’ (The Spotnicks); Fur Elise as ‘Roti Calliope’ (Group X). Bizet’s Farandole from L’Arlesienne suite as ‘Farandole’ (Love Sculpture); Khachaturian’s Sabre Dance as Sabre Dance (Love Sculpture). There are a great number more. I have only scratched the surface of them. Classical music provides a rich seam of great music to be plundered for the instro groups of the 60s. Being a 60s music geek who specialises in instrumentals of course helps! Choosing Classical music as the originals is a bit of a cheat I suppose, but one cannot argue with the surprise element — originals by Rossini, Grieg, Tchaikovsky, Bach, Bizet, and Khachaturian. Check the tracks out on YouTube.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Barbara Young Capalbo

response.answer_text: Maybe someone already mentioned this, but Manfred Mann’s cover of Springsteen’s Blinded by the Light far surpassed the original, in my opinion, and succeeded in making the song famous. Springsteen’s original version came out in 1973 on his first album, which sold few copies and ended up doing nothing on the charts. A few years later, after Springsteen had become famous with Born to Run, other bands started picking songs of his to cover. The Manfred Mann version of Blinded by the Light gave the song a killer synthesizer riff, clean production (something lacking on the Springsteen version), and a few memorable touches of its own including someone banging out “Chopsticks” on the piano at one point and a vocal “round” of two voices toward the end. Amazingly, it all worked, and the song became a number one U.S. hit in early 1977. Ironically, this remains the only Springsteen song ever to reach number one, and it wasn’t his version! I was just five years old when the Manfred Mann version came out and I remember loving it at the time (I’m one of those lucky kids whose mom was into rock music and always had top-40 radio on in the 70’s). I had no idea until years later that it had originally been by Springsteen. I think that came as a surprise to a lot of people who hadn’t followed Springsteen’s early career. I like the Springsteen version, too, for that matter. But they’re like two different songs. If you do look for the Manfred Mann version, by the way, make sure it’s the full version, not the version with a couple of minutes removed that was used for the single (a common and annoying practice at the time). I find that the single feels half baked. You need the long keyboard and guitar break in the middle to appreciate the song fully. I’m a big Bruce fan, and I love the Mann version. However, I think a lot of Springsteen fans hate it. To me, a good song is a good song. Sure, the Manfred Mann version added lots of electronics to what had been a “purer” song by Bruce, and the cover does remove a few verses (there were too many in the original song, I think). For me, the cover just works so well. What did Bruce think of the cover going to number one? Well, another Quora writer was probably accurate in describing Springsteen’s reaction as “bemused.” That’s based on peoples’ misunderstanding of the word “deuce” in the Mann version, which caused many to think it was a reference to a feminine hygiene product rather than a “deuce” coupe, as Springsteen had intended. In the video below, Springsteen describes that confusion, then adds, “What can I say? The public spoke, and they were right.” To me, this sounds like him acknowledging the cover was better than the original, but that’s subject to interpretation.

A great cover should bring something new to a song, show it in a new light, or (best yet) find something new within the song that was waiting to come out. Some examples: Coil’s cover of Tainted Love. For those born after AIDS became manageable, its hard to understand the AIDS epidemic, but this version and video… if you don’t get chills, I don’t know what’s wrong with you. It contrasts wonderfully with the sassy Gloria Jones original and the bouncy Soft Cell cover:  Smashing Pumpkins’ cover of Landslide. I don’t think there was ever an official video because the song was a B-side, but it was the standout track from their stellar B-side collection, Pisces Iscariot (probably my favorite Pumpkins “album”). This one stands out because of what it brought out of the Pumpkins. No Billy Corgan vocal histrionics. No intensely layering. No irony. Pure talent on an amazing song, now a standard covered by many.  Joe Cocker’s cover of “With A Little Help From My Friends”. Yeah, others have mentioned it, but the original is a joke, Cocker turned it into an anthem:  Jonathan Coulton’s cover of “Baby Got Back”. This should have been the last nail in the coffin of reflective, moody covers of silly pop songs. That didn’t happen, but it’s still a gem:  And in the interest of ending on a weird note, my favorite Yugoslavian industrial band, Laibach, covered the whole soundtrack from The Sound of Music. They performed it live in North Korea: Liberation Day (2016) - IMDb. Here’s a very dark rendition of “So Long, Farewell”, replete with socialist symbolism:

Pop-punk band The Ataris scored a hit with a cover of Don Henley's “The Boys of Summer”. No Doubt had a hit with their updated version of Talk Talk's “It's My Life”. R&B vocal group Az Yet revisited Chicago's “Hard to Say I'm Sorry”, with a little help from former Chicago frontman Peter Cetera. Tom Jones had a comeback hit in 1989 with his rendition of Prince's “Kiss”. '80s Glam Metal bad boys Motley Crue resurrected the '70s Brownsville Station nugget, “Smokin' in the Boys' Room.” Britney Spears covered Sonny and Cher's “The Beat Goes On” on her 1999 debut, and belted out her version of The Rolling Stones' “(I Can't Get No) Satisfaction” on her sophomore album the following year. Country-pop sensations Rascal Flatts covered Tom Cochrane's driving “Life Is a Highway”. Alternative jam band Counting Crows do a great cover of Joni Mitchell's “Big Yellow Taxi.” Cat Stevens' “The First Cut Is the Deepest” has been revisited at least twice, with Rod Stewart in 1976 and Sheryl Crow in 2003. And of course, in 1986 rock and rap crashed head-on with Aerosmith and Run-D.M.C.'s version of “Walk This Way.”
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Barbara Young Capalbo

response.answer_text: Otis Redding’s “Respect” was a big hit for him in 1965 but Aretha Franklin’s 1967 version, a surprise cover then, blew it out of the water. Otis Redding made a great cover of the Rolling Stone’s “Satisfaction.” The question asked “… the best …” not the best known so I’ll move to the world of jazz. In 1949, Saxophonist James Moody made a version of a standard song written in 1935, Jimmy McHugh’s “I’m In The Mood For Love” but Moody never played the melody. This composing technique, long used by jazz musicians, is called a “contrafact,” a legitimate means of reserving royalties to the new melody’s composer. In Moody’s case, the new melody was improvised on the spot in the studio but he failed to give it a new song title. This recording became a surprise hit, arguably Moody’s best known recording. In 1952, vocalese lyricist and singer Eddie Jefferson put words to Moody’s complete performance including the pianist’s solo. This version was recorded by King Pleasure (with Blossom Dearie) in 1954 as “Moody’s Mood For Love.” In the jazz world, King Pleasure’s version became so popular then and into the 1970’s that younger listeners were stunned when they heard the 1949 original by James Moody. BTW, Jimmy McHugh sued for copyright infringement but had to settle for half of future royalties, since the artistic modifications by Moody and Jefferson were considered “fair use” under the contrafact doctrine.
response.upvotes: Answer requested by Barbara Young Capalbo

response.answer_text: MONEY by BARRETT STRONG made famous by THE BEATLES but given an alternative treatment by THE FLYING LIZARDS LEAVING ON A JET PLANE by JOHN DENVER but given a better haunting folk treatment by PETER PAUL AND MARY AMERICA by PAUL SIMON given a prog rock treatment by YES. SEVEN BRIDGES ROAD by STEVE YOUNG made famous by THE EAGLES on their first live album. WHISKY IN THE JAR, a traditional folk song given the ROCK treatment by THIN LIZZY ABSOLUTELY SWEET MARIE contemporary folk song by BOB DYLAN given a brilliant rock treatment by JASON AND THE SCORCHERS Ditto for MR TAMBOURINE MAN covered by THE BYRDS STOP YOUR SOBBING by THE KINKS given an epic treatment by THE PRETENDERS I could go on forever……….

I see there are 35 answers already, and my phone battery is low. Still, without taking time to scroll and see others answers (sorry for being lazy), I’ll offer two of my favourites. Astronomy Domine - original artist: Pink Floyd, cover by Voivod. I watched a video last night with four guys talking about their favourite Voivod albums. Everyone agreed that Voivod’s cover of this Pink Floyd classic was one of the best if the not best cover song ever!  Eleanor Rigby - original artist: The Beatles, covered by Zoot Before Rick Springfield went overseas to find fortune in Amer Continue Reading

This is a topic I could go on for quite a bit, but I’ll limit myself to these examples. One of my favorite covers of all time is Jerry Williams’ version of Working Class Hero. Where John Lennon’s original gives me the impression of someone who is defeated and cynical, this version is filled with fresh pain and pathos, a fresh wound compared to Lennon’s old scars. When he hits the refrain I get chills every time.  A more internationally well known example is Johnny Cash’s cover of Nine Inch Nails’ Hurt, which many don’t even realize is a cover. Cash’s life experi Continue Reading

Usually, if a song is a cover that I haven’t heard before, I’ll like the cover better than the original. So it kind of disqualifies them for an answer to this. Straight covers bore me to tears, if you are going to be unoriginal, at least add some originality to it. That being said I guess my favorite would be Celtic Frost’s cover of Wall of Voodoo’s Mexican Radio. Some punk covers are fun if they’re done tongue in cheek, like the Nip Drivers cover of Duran Duran’s Rio or the Butthole Surfers mutation of Black Sabbath’s Sweet Leaf called Sweet Loaf. But straight covers usually sound inferior to Continue Reading

A2A What are some of the best, most surprising, covers of original songs made famous by other musicians? A cover that surprised me in the best way isn’t a cover of a song turned into another version of that song. But it is a surprising cover and an original song. The cover is an original musical cover of a classic science fiction short story. The combination of genres is really fun. The band Deadmaus created a song all about a chapter in The Illustrated Man by Ray Bradbury, “The Veldt”. In case you are not familiar with it, The Illustrated Man is a wonderful and consuming collection of short stori Continue Reading

I tried to choose songs where I like both the original and the cover. “Tears of a Clown”, The Beat/English Beat’s ska cover of Smokey Robinson’s soul classic.  “Willin’”, Linda Ronstadt covering Little Feat. One of my favorite covers of one of my favorite Little Feat songs.  “Have You Ever Seen the Rain?”, Willie Nelson and his daughter Paula covering Creedence Clearwater Revival. Haunting and beautiful.  "(What's So Funny 'Bout) Peace, Love, and Understanding", Elvis Costello covering Nick Lowe.  Continue Reading

Oh, I don’t know which are “the best” or “most surprising,” so I’ll just talk about one I like. Remember Three Dog Night? If you grew up in the 70s, you do, because their music was everywhere (especially in the first half of that decade), and if you’re like me, you enjoyed their music and didn’t much care that the critics never had much respect for them. (They didn’t write their own songs, you see, and that was unforgivable in the world that the Beatles created.) Decades later, I started listening to them again, and realized that, damn, this is good stuff. Granted, they made a few questionable c Continue Reading

Confession time: when I first heard Jai Paul’s cover of Jennifer Taylor’s “Crush,” I had no idea it wasn’t Jai’s song. (Yes, I’ve spent my life living under a rock. Fight me.) But really, my pop culture ignorance aside, hearing it from that perspective, Jai’s version just fits gives the vibe of the song soooo much more potential that I would’ve guessed he wrote it. What makes it better is that the choice of song, and the execution, is so random. It’s literally the only cover he’s ever released, it’s weird and choppy, the sound bears practically no resemblance to the original’s. It’s something mos Continue Reading

The first song that came to my mind (other than WALH obviously) is "Killing Me Softly”, a song composed by Charles Fox and Norman Gimbel in 1971. The story was that Lori Lieberman, a singer at the time, was so impressed by Don MacLean ( of American Pie fame) concert performance that she told the aforementioned Gimbel et Fox about it. From that they wrote the song for her and Lieberman released her version of the song in 1972, but it did not become a hit. In 1973 The great R&B singer/pianist Roberta Flack covered it and it became a number-one hit in the United States and Canada. The song was la Continue Reading

Most of the best known great covers have been mentioned by others here; Hurt- Johnny Cash, A little Help From my Friends - Joe Cocker, All Along the Watchtower - Jimi Hendrix. A recent song written by Lady Gaga for the movie A Star is Born, was the song Shallow. It was a great song but last year was covered by the Metal singer, Floor Jansen on the Dutch TV show Beste Zangers where she sang it to the nights’ guest Emma Heesters who had also done a cover for her well known Youtube channels. Floor’s version took a totally different and surprising take on the song that immediately grabbed the atte Continue Reading

First one to come to my mind is “You Keep Me Hangin’ On” by the Supremes in 1966, covered by Vanilla Fudge the following year. Fudge took the fast-tempoed pop song, slowed it down to almost half the original tempo and made it a heavy rock song. It also rocketed the NY rock band into the limelight. Girls version:  Boys version:  As an aside… I saw Vanilla Fudge in San Diego around 1968. They blew the headliner away, Jimi Hendrix!!! Maybe Hendrix had an off night or maybe they were just that good.

I love Joe Cocker as an answer, and I would ask everyone to watch him performing ‘Come Together’ from ‘Across The Universe’, in which he plays three different characters. I never imagined I’d hear a better version than The Beatles’, but there it is. The first song that came to my mind, and it was the biggest hit this artist ever had as a single, was a song written by Bob Dylan. Totally transformed into an entirely different song, ‘All Along The Watchtower’, by Jimi Hendrix, blew me away. Give it a listen, and then try and remember that it was written by Dylan. I think it’s off of ‘Nashville Sky Continue Reading

So many to choose from. I will give you my three favorites. The Beatles “Twist and Shout” is simply one of the great covers of all time. I heard it long before I heard the Isley Brothers original (which I also love). No doubt the Liverpool lads put their own spin on it to make that version of the song very much thier own. When I first heard Bruce Springsteen do “Trapped” during a 1984 concert, I assumed it was a new song by him. I had never heard the Jimmy Cliff original that was done back in 1972. Springsteen would release a live version of “Trapped” as part of the “We are the World” album in  Continue Reading
